title: How many active California fires with 10,000 or more acres burned will be reported by the LA Times' California Fire Map as of 1 October 2020?
preds: Still about 17 active fires of that size 4 days out.

Four days left.
16 active 10k+ acre fires and one more growing close.
3 are 98% contained but even optimistically that brings us from 16 to 13.
No heavy rains anticipated according to NOAA. If there were, I'm guessing fires take longer than 4 days to be contained even with the help of rain.

Based on the rate at which fires dropped off the list between 9/20 (the date of my first estimate) and  now, the date of my latest estimate, I see almost zero chance of there being less than 4 fires on that list. Currently the August Complex, Castle, Creek, Dolan, Red Salmon Complex, and SQF Complex fires are all above 10k acres burned and less than 60% contained.

I predict there will be 10 active fires (+2/-2) with more than 10,000 or more acres burned on 01 October 2020 with a certainty of 90%.
There seems to be a borderline between those fires that started in September and have got contained to a large degree very fast, and those fires that have been burning for 40 days or more and that have mostly burned 100,000 acres or more, when it comes to "containability". As soon as a fire has crossed 100,000 it appears it keeps burning for several reasons, such as a lack of water for containment or as a natural barrier, the geographical structure that promotes stronger winds, the type of local woods or vegetation that is affected and maybe even the impassable landscape.
It seems resources like firefighting planes are allocated to fresh fires in order to put out fires before they grow too large to be contained easily, imho, and of course to places where people's lives and livelihoods are in acute danger.
The fact that even large fire complexes such as  Scu Lightning Complex

98% which are very close to civilization and larger cities, have mainained their containment status of  >95% for more than one week now but are still not extinct, underscores to me how hard it becomes with a certain size of fires and especially complexes.

Scu Lightning Complex (Includes 3 fires)

since their containment status is already near 100% and they are not expected to grow further. The two fires that may be added to the list are
Slink (which already qualifies, but containment is also high at 86%)
Devil (which may grow to more than 10,000 acres before 01 Oct or be merged into the neighboring Slater fire. Though there is no additional info about Slater, it seems it will be large enough to qualify even alone, and still active, but that is just guessing. The 10% uncertainty I assign to a very much higher number of fires, as the "North Complex" alone includes 23 individual named fires and I cannot conclude from the questions remarks, whether these will be counted individually or not, but it will likely not matter. It remains between a rock and a hard place.
Given the fire data, I do not see the number dropping below 4, but I'm keeping the other options open to account for possible rainstorms.

Summary:
>4 seems almost certain at this point but I would only feel comfortable with a 90% if I were more experienced in subject matter.  80% seems too low given all of the above, what other forecasters are saying, and the exceptional nature of this fire season according to the data and qualified experts on CA and federal wildlife websites. Only 10 days remain to resolve 18 massive fires. Even if they merged 3-fold there would still be 4 fires. Detail:
9/20/20 9500+ acre fires in CA
LA times says: 18
Wikipedia says: 19 (*18 if you count the merger) [[An interesting measurement phenomenon to keep in mind is that the LA times appear to be counting 2 massive fires that physically merge as 1 fire. The following 100,000+ acre fires now count as 1 active fire "Elkhorn (August Complex North & West Zones)" + "August Complex (August Complex South Zone)".]] Evidence-1 (E1): "New cases"
The latest fire ("Snow") started on the 17th and in only 4 days has reached 7k acres and is only 20% contained.
Conclusions: A fire can spread to nearly the 9500 acre threshold in a matter of days even this late into the season and this late into fire containment efforts.
So,
What is the probability that new fires appear over the next 10 days to the cutoff date? [at least 1 seems possible] Evidence-2 (E2): "Fire Merging"
Fires that marge reduce total active fire count by 1. UNLESS La Times decides to change how they count.
Conclusions: If half the fires merged once by end of September, we'd still have 9 fires. If the fires merged twice, we'd still have 4 (the poll threshold) or more. So merging isnt really very telling but something to keep an eye on.
So,
What is the probability of a multi-merge? [doesnt really matter]
What is the probability LA Times stops counting merges? [doesnt really matter] Evidence-3 (E3): "Baseline comparison"

No amounts of precipitation worth mentioning to be expected for CA by 26 September 2020. There is still a massive high pressure area offshore CA blocking every rain front and diverting it either to north-western states, British Columbia (CA) or towards Mexico. Most Fire Complexes, such as the August Complex, are combined large fires which for themselves and in sum would resolve the question "4 or more" each. They typically have large areas burned (500,000 acres or more), have multiple fire "hot spots", contain a "mandatory evacuation zone" of significant size, are located in rather impassable areas in general, and have a low containment status. If the complexes lack a containment status, to me it is NOT a sign of the situation being under control but, to the contrary, a lack of data or a size of the area burnt so far that has not even been managed  to be explored in detail so far.
All signs point to considerable numbers of large fires continuing to burn until mother nature decides to assist.

On the one hand, the number of fires that are both 10,000+ acres and less than 50% contained is down to 8. Less than a week ago, it was 12. So things are still on track to get below 4 by the end of the month. On the other hand, the Scu Lightning Complex fire has been stuck at 98% for days now, so there's a lot I don't understand. Therefore I'm bumping 4 or more up to 50%, since maybe the final few percentage points of containment is harder than I thought.

Northern California is predicted to get rain at the end of this week, which should help with the Red Salmon Complex and other fires up there. The number of wildfires that are both over 10k acres and under 50% contained is now at 11, down from 12 yesterday. Adjusting odds accordingly.

I just found a resource by the NOAA, the "Rapid Refresh" imagery for relative humidity in the 850hPa surface.
It sadly confirms my view that there's virtually no chance any time soon for any rainfalls, since the entire Pacific coast and even large areas offshore are covered with a bowl of extremely dry air, which has an unusually low relative humidity of 20% or less. https://rapidrefresh.noaa.gov/displayImage.cgi?image=rh850image&width=806&model=rr&title=RAP Unless there are massive rainfalls statewide, most fires will remain uncontained whatever resources the Cal fire fighters bring up.
Except from a few small thunderstorms in northern CA on Thursday 17 September 2020 into Friday 18 Sep 2020, no precipitation at all is expected until 22 September 2020, as of today. To the contrary, the thunderstorms' lightning, instead of bringing relief, could ignite a wave of new fires, which would have 12 or more days to go and grow to 10,000 acres or more... A really shocking, hopeless situation. I wonder if federal funds would do any good, but POTUS still seems unwilling to support Democrat states. At least, the Republican rally in Reno was cancelled due to the situation. Maybe this fire season will reach unique catastrophic magnitudes, and if FEMA or lawmakers fail to support, it will even influence voters on November 3rd.
Fascinating, how and to what degree the GJO questions seem to be inter-dependent...

Learned from 2019 fire season:
 - there were only 4 fires that were above 10,000 acres (so today's 20 fires is high above normal - even last year was considered high)
 - on average, the 4 10,000+ acre fires were put out in about 2.5 weeks after the start date NPR story (https://www.npr.org/2020/09/04/909668879/whats-driving-california-s-biggest-ever-wildfire-season)
 - "In an average season, 300,000 acres burn. This year more than 2 million acres have been scorched — and the season isn't over yet." Currently 3 weeks left in the month, so all 20 fires currently ablaze could be put out before the end of the month, but its unlikely that they will all be put out in the average 2.5 weeks. That, and there's a high chance there will be additional fires as this LA Times article says the worst of the fire season doesn't usually happen until October: https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-09-08/powerful-winds-return-amid-californias-biggest-fire-season There is a chance that there are extra rains or favorable wind, but even that will likely not bring the number down to below 4.
I don't take any satisfaction in this update. It's really awful what's happing out there. Tracking the reported numbers for the past 5 days increases my confidence that there will be 4 or more....

This is an interesting question on a topic I know nothing about.  The situation on Sept 1 was exceptional so I'm not going to let that anchor my thinking. I'm trying to figure out a base rate.  I consulted with the great and powerful wikipedia and I was not disappointed. I learned that there aren't very many big fires, but they tend to last a long time. This tells me that this is more about how long the current fires last than how many more fires start. So noodling it, if we were NOT starting the month with a bunch of big fires I would call my base rate to be about 3 based on the 2014-2019 average of >10k fires.  However there is another way to view the base rate. Almost all of the active fires started around Aug 16-19. So they would need to still be active about 40-45 days after starting. It is currently 20 days or so. Historically about 40% of fires that lasted at least 20 days made it to 40 days. There are roughly 8-10 burning at the moment (technally there are a bunch of others that are not fully contained but I'm not counting those). I would estimate that roughly 4 of those would still be burning. On average 1.5 big fires start in Sept so i bump that up to 5.5 as my estimate.  I should note that 3 of the fires have the potential to merge, so I'll subtract 1. Call it 4.5.  I'm going with 4 or more as my main bucket.  https://www.predictiveservices.nifc.gov/outlooks/monthly_seasonal_outlook.pdf

Vegetation is supposed to be very dry, daily maximum temperatures in CA will range from 34°C (northern CA) to 45°C (south-east corner of CA) until at least Thursday 10 September 2020, and zero precipitation to be expected for whole CA until at least Sunday 13 September 2020.
Most wildfires this season are the result of lightning during thunderstorms, so we are basically talking about a very low probability of additional wildfires through that way of ignition which could grow to 10,000 or more acres. The questions then would be:
/for how long will each individual of the current fires go on burning before it will be extinct and considered no longer active?
/how many of the remaining fires <10,000 acres (currently 29, 16 of which have a "containment" status 10% to 98%, 13 have no such status and either lack detailed info or are already considered as contained) will reach the required criteria by 01 October 2020, and will remain active as well?
However, there are other causes for wildfires to start, most importantly human intent, and technical (or human) failure. The 2018 Camp Fire (153,336 acres burned, "was the deadliest and most destructive wildfire in California history") was almost surely ignited by faulty power lines belonging to the utility company Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_Fire_%282018%29
Drought as a precondition of wildfires will thus advance additional wildfires which will be ignited in other ways than lightning. Severe winds or fire storms will determine, how fast the affected area will grow. So far winds are likely to play a subordinated role. Due to uncertainties around the speed of the spread of individual fires and complexes, the CA fire fighters' capacity, and the scope at which CA fire fighters' response and success is impaired by the number of simultaneous fires on large areas to bring down each of the individual fires, the first forecast can only be a rough estimate, data is needed to be observed for at least a week for a more certain position. However, the probability of 4 or more large fires
a) still active
b) grown from < 10,000 acres to > 10,000 acres and still active
c) newly ignited and growing sufficiently fast to surpass 10,000 acres before 01 October 2020
is overwhelmingly large, I would guess.
